sentence: Wall Street continued its meteoric rise on Wednesday with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 setting new all-time highs as sizable gains in interest-rate sensitive sectors upstaged a selling spree in stocks of drug makers.
The pharmaceutical sector came under pressure after Time magazine's "Person of the Year" interview with President-elect Donald Trump circulated through the financial markets.

Although Trump was not specific in either his target or method, his comment to "bring down drug prices" spooked investors, causing shares of Dow component stocks Merck ( MRK ), Pfizer ( PFE ) and Johnson & Johnson ( JNJ ) to wither.
Fortunately, the remaining component stocks were sharply higher, led by gains in Home Depot ( HD ), Nike ( NKE ) and Visa (V) that drove the blue-chip index as much as 300 points higher.
Despite the gains in equities, the price of gold increased by $4.30, making today only the fourth time in 15 days that the precious metal has traded higher.
Treasury yields were lower across the yield curve with the 10-year note richer to 2.349% and the 30-yr bond yield topping 3.00%.
Wednesday's economic data was light and had little impact on an already bullish market.
Job openings decreased slightly in November to 5.534 million, but beat expectations of 5.50 million jobs available.
This followed an upward revision to October to 5.631 million from 5.486 million, initially.
Thursday's economic data includes initial jobless claims for the week ended Dec 3, expected to decrease by 13,000 to 255,000.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(-) SIGM (-27.74%) Beats Q2 earnings estimates by two cents on below consensus revenue

(-) PES (-15.67%) Priced its upsized 10.5 million share offering at $5.75 per share

(-) FTK (-15.33%) FourWorld Capital analysis raises questions about efficacy and value of lead fracking agent CnF
